Authors:
Tracey V Steinrucken, Anil K.H. Raghavendra, Jeff R Powell,
Andrew Bissett, Rieks D van Klinken
Title:
Triggering dieback in an invasive plant: endophyte diversity
and pathogenicity
Keywords:
Parkinsonia aculeata, fungal community, inoculation trial,
weeds, biological control
Abstract:
Dieback is a progressive reduction in plant population
health, resulting in the death of plant parts, often followed by tree
death. It is prevalent in many invasive woody weeds in Australia and has
been suggested as a potential mechanism for biocontrol of these species.
Parkinsonia aculeata L. (parkinsonia) is an invasive tree in northern
Australia. It has naturalised across a wide range of climatic zones and
some populations have been heavily reduced by dieback occurrence. The
cause/s of dieback in parkinsonia remain elusive, although fungal
endophyte communities have been previously implicated. In this study, we
characterised the fungal community of healthy and dieback-affected
parkinsonia using culture-based techniques, and identified isolates via
amplicon sequencing of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS). Eight
isolates, identified as pathogens, were selected for a 10-week
pathogenicity trial on parkinsonia seedlings, using water stress
treatments (drought and inundation) to exacerbate systemic infection and
dieback-like symptoms. We isolated a taxonomically diverse fungal
community, representing 54 unique species from 25 families. Communities
were similar across healthy and dieback-affected plants, but differed by
plant tissue. Of the eight pathogens tested in the pathogenicity trial,
inoculation with Lasiodiplodia pseudotheobromae, Botryosphaeria dothidea
and Pestalotiopsis mangiferae resulted in the largest lesions. Systemic
infection or dieback-like symptoms were not observed in any treatment,
despite plant stress induced by drought or inundation. We concluded that
underbark inoculation of parkinsonia with the tested putative fungal
pathogens is unlikely to result in dieback, which has implications for
future work in biocontrol of parkinsonia.
